Managed to get rid of a lot of it, will keep at it. IntelliJ is remarkably frustrating to deal with regarding this, I can't seem to find a way to completely disable every autoformatter that it's using.

> Managed to get rid of a lot of it, will keep at it. IntelliJ is remarkably frustrating to deal with regarding this, I can't seem to find a way to completely disable every autoformatter that it's using.

Hmmm, try going to `Settings -> Tools -> Actions on Save` and basically unticking everything. You don't really want these things to happen unless it's your own project anyway, or the project's style is *strictly* enforced, otherwise you'll just get diff-hell :P

Never had any of them checked. I think it's that all the plugins have different styles and IntelliJ isn't sure what to stick to. Mostly it's that they use spaces vs. tabs for indentation or have different rules about line wrapping and whatnot. Even forcing it to not format .java files still has it make some changes for some reason (eg removing indents on empty lines is apparently not formatting).

> Might be worth going through and undoing the formatting though as this is an extremely contentful PR and it's hard to review the PR.

Worth noting that Github has an "Ignore whitespace changes" in the review menu if you're not already aware

It's only "not actually necessary" because the tests that need it have been commented out. If you uncomment them, you'll see why it's necessary, but PseudoServer actually needs to be updated, which is why drafted #393.

> I'm not extending internal Bukkit classes

Yeah, PseudoServer has the Minestom approach [of only adding what you need], whereas extending CraftServer would be the PaperMC approach [of disabling what you don't want]. PseudoServer was added back in the 1.16.4 days (before even the move to Gradle) to avoid spinning up a whole server (and figuring out where the server files should go and when they should be cleaned up) just to test some item stuff. Now that we have [:runServer](https://github.com/jpenilla/run-task), this is *far* less of an issue.
mockbukkit btw
btw, mockbukkit != craftbukkit

If you intend to go through with this, you should probably remove junit and the test source set altogether too. We simply do not have well any enough managed or organised projects for it, and the stuff we need to test for, like item matching, requires a minimum level of server bootstrapping. It would probably be better to move any test stuff to `civmodcore-test` with a custom run command that starts a short-lived server instead.

While it's not really necessary, it might be worth using [PersistentDataTypes.BOOLEAN](https://github.com/CivMC/Civ/blob/4527f032f8fe78a00a25780cba16a7d47eafd25f/plugins/civmodcore-paper/src/main/java/vg/civcraft/mc/civmodcore/pdc/PersistentDataTypes.java#L15) instead of PersistentDataType.INTEGER. The code will be a little longer but will be more readable and will require less storage (though is a micro-optimisation).

Now that I think about it. The name is probably why ItemExchange didn't recognize it. üíÄ
Yep it broke for me as well

> Now that I think about it. The name is probably why ItemExchange didn't recognize it. üíÄ

That could be the cause of some unintended plugin-load ordering, but it should NOT cause the error. JukeAlert is supposed to be a soft-dependency; ItemExchange is suppose to work even if JukeAlert isn't there.

The error is also completely baffling, it's a `NoClassDefFoundError`, which means a class is being used in a non-reflective manner (eg: an instance is being constructed with `new`), but the class isn't present.

The missing class is `LoggableAction`, right?. That by itself is bizarre because nothing in ItemExchange references `LoggableAction`: the class `ShopPurchaseAction` extends `LoggablePlayerAction` and *that* implements `LoggableAction`, so... why is the missing class `LoggableAction` and not `LoggablePlayerAction`? Those are both JukeAlert classes.

Also, `ShopPurchaseAction` is only interacted with in two places:

1. Inside a lambda that's registered as an action-factory to JukeAlert, something that only happens if JukeAlert is enabled.

2. Inside an event listener that's only registered if JukeAlert is enabled.

So how in the hell is this class being used?!

Ohhhh, okay, just figured out what's happening: the action-factory lambda gets hoisted by javac into a sibling method:
![image](https://github.com/CivMC/Civ/assets/52572989/431a770f-5be8-4f62-a321-c1032d5b7e4d)

So when the class is evaluated, it finds the method and tries to evaluate its return type, LoggableAction, which isn't loaded. The only fix to this is to deliberately avoid the lambda-isation and turn it into a sibling class.

Can you explain what this does

> Can you explain what this does

This PR Enables checks automatically to run on all PRs, which will run `gradle check`, and `yamllint` (errors currently ignored until we fix them all).

You can see the checks ran on this PR as a requirement before merging, taking 1 minute to ensure that the project builds, tests pass, and yaml files are formatted correctly (which will be more important especially when plugin config gets moved here). If we add code style checks and such to gradle, that will also be part of the check task

It also adds a workflow that comments with an easy link to the built artifact on the pr for testing, the output of which can be seen here: https://github.com/CivMC/CivModCore/pull/98#issuecomment-1849098604. Once this is merged that will start working, since the workflow needs to be on `main`

Why do we have so many random utility classes wtf

These `More*` classes are entirely my fault :P it's a mixture of me being younger and dumber, Minecraft/Paper having fewer useful shaded dependencies, and Java having fewer static utilities. For example, [`java.lang.Math.clamp()`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Math.html#clamp\(double,double,double\)) was only added in Java 21. [`java.util.List.of()`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api/java.base/java/util/List.html#of\(E...\)) was added in Java 9, but we only stopped compiling against Java 8 in [December 2020](https://github.com/CivClassic/style-guide/pull/10).

Hmmm, starting to wonder whether this refactor is moot: the server is just the compiled output of this monorepo; there'll *NEVER* be a question over whether NameLayer, or Citadel, or JukeAlert, is missing, unless we delete those plugins from the monorepo... which is unlikely. In addition, Okx has said that we should stop pretending that we aren't the only ones who consume our APIs ([reference](https://discord.com/channels/912074050086502470/919348449407815680/1244821453707280445)), and SoundTech has said that all changes must be tested with a local docker instance ([reference](https://discord.com/channels/912074050086502470/952314898317189120/1243925834755084389)) because it replicates the server as closely as possible. With these things in mind, I'm wondering whether it'd be better to yeet this boilerplate altogether and convert all our soft-dependencies into hard-dependencies.
This should be good, but I didn't want to hijack the test server from 1.20 to test it too hard. We can merge it, merge it up to 1.20, and then test it and make any fixes as needed.

Given how fraught with bugs combat loggers have been, it might be worth looking into custom Paper patches. These issues all stem from CombatTagPlus being a plugin, and so its approach can only be to duplicate the player entity upon logout. But this has led to many, *many* bugs, including dupes, because combat-loggers are consequential: they're meant to *be* the player.

Whereas, if combat loggers were implemented through patches (or mixins), you wouldn't need to create a duplicate entity. You could just prevent the server from deleting the player-entity when they logout. There'd likely still be issues to iron out, but having the same entity to work with would be a lot easier than playing Whack-A-Mole with these combat-logger bugs.
